column4: you can find the processes with lsof or netstat -p, if that's what you mean
thanks. I'll try that
do you happen to have an idea why this happens when I write apache2 in terminal. Error: netstat -p
do you happen to have an idea why this happens when I write apache2 in terminal. Error: (13)Permission denied: make_sock: could not bind to address [::] :80
if you are running as an ordinary user, you can't access ports < 1024
I used sudo.
perhaps another process still have the port?
have any idea of which process might use it?
do this:   lsof -i :80
Didn't get any feedback.
the command didn't respond. Just prompting for another command. Just as there wasn't any processes using :80
then that's not the reason.  Hmm, what's the exact error again?
(98)Address already in use: make_sock: could not bind to address [::] :80
If you do netstat -na | grep 80       you get nothing?
I get some stuff. unix  2      [ ACC ]      STREAM     LISTENING     11880    private/relay
no, it has to be in the external section and look like this:      0.0.0.0:80
assuming it is listening for all connections.  just look for :80
tcp        0      0 0.0.0.0:80              0.0.0.0:*               LISTEN <- that was on the top of what I just pasted.
ok, there's your problem.  Now use -p to find out what process that is
I'm sorry. But I haven't used linux for too long. Anyways,  netstat -p | procces name? :P
netstat -nap | grep :80
thanks alot :) I found the procces and killed it. Apache is able to start now.
